title: IRC Archive for channel #xwiki - XWiki
content:

08:46 <sburjan``> has joined #xwiki  
08:47 <sburjan``> has left #xwiki  
08:57 <jvdrean> has joined #xwiki  
09:03 <jvdrean> has quit  
09:23 <sburjan> has joined #xwiki  
09:41 <arkub> has joined #xwiki  
09:44 <vmassol> guys I've modified http://contrib.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Main/ a bit  
09:45 <vmassol> I'll send a mail  
09:46 <jstoldt> why is the code box with parent not colored, when the last codebox is?  
10:01 <+sburjan> hello  
10:01 <+sburjan> vmassol: I am allowed to add a non-existing user to a group. this bug goes to XAADMINISTRATION, right ?  
10:02 <vmassol> sburjan: you can put it there and it'll be moved by the dev who fixes it if it goers elsewhere  
10:04 <+sburjan> ok.hould I put in the latest version ? Unreleased yet version ? Or in latest released. This happens on 3.0 snapshot  
10:05 <sabageru> has joined #xwiki  
10:08 <vmassol> if it happens also on the last released version then you should use that one  
10:09 <+sburjan> yes, but I don't know which XE uses the latest released version.  
10:09 <vmassol> release plan  
10:09 <vmassol> http://dev.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Community/ReleasePlans  
10:09 <vmassol> or even better:  
10:10 <vmassol> http://svn.xwiki.org/svnroot/xwiki/enterprise/tags/xwiki-enterprise-2.7/pom.xml  
10:10 <vmassol> it says:  
10:10 <vmassol>  <platform.administration.version>1.44</platform.administration.version>  
10:10 <vmassol> in any case you don't need to know this  
10:10 <vmassol> all you need to know is whether the pb happens in 1.44  
10:11 <+sburjan> yes, but I'm not on 2.7, I'm on 3.0 snap  
10:11 <+sburjan> knowing the svn stuff i good also .. I want to become a dev one day, don't forget that  
10:11 <vmassol> yep this is why I pointed you to them  
10:12 <vmassol> normally sorin you should import 1.44  
10:12 <vmassol> and verify the bug is there  
10:12 <vmassol> then you can report against it  
10:12 <vmassol> now you may take a guess  
10:12 <vmassol> that it's on 1.44  
10:12 <vmassol> the dev can fix that if he finds it's a regression that wasn't there in 1.44  
10:13 <vmassol> of course better be acurate when you can  
10:13 <vmassol> gtg bb in 15  
10:13 <+sburjan> yes. I could start a 2.7 xe and see if it reproduces, and if reproduces I can report it on 1.44  
10:14 <+sburjan> actually I'm gonna do that  
10:24 <lucaa> has joined #xwiki  
10:24 <jstoldt> gotta love IBM... move your server to another building in the same complex and all the nice setup you've done prior to that is screwed!  
10:25 <jstoldt> different matter, i noticed that in svn revision 33938 a couple of new translation strings were introduced  
10:25 <jstoldt> however, i can't see them on l10n.xwiki.org  
10:25 <jstoldt> any particular reason for that?  
10:28 <+sburjan> XAADMINISTRATION-199  
10:29 <+sburjan> vmassol: FYI today I will start working on Manual Test Plan you told Silvia yesterday  
10:35 <jstoldt> I'd like to propose that core.copy.targetdoc.hint is changed to "Desired location for the copied page" or "Desired location for the copy" or "Desired location for the copy of the page"  
10:36 <jstoldt> reason being that "Desired location for the copy page" could be misinterpreted as the target address for the ?xpage=copy Page, IMO  
10:37 <vmassol> jstoldt: there's a scheduler that imports new trnaslations regularly I think  
10:37 <jstoldt> ah, thanks  
10:37 <vmassol> yep  
10:37 <vmassol> (just checked)  
10:37 <vmassol> next fire time: Fri Jan 14 02:00:00 CET 2011  
10:37 <jstoldt> ok, thanks again  
10:37 <vmassol> I can force it to run now for you if you want  
10:38 <vmassol> if you're eager to contribute new transaltions :)  
10:38 <jstoldt> nope, it's fine  
10:38 <jstoldt> leaves me some more work for tomorrow ;)  
10:38 <vmassol> ok  
10:38 <vmassol> sburjan: ok  
10:40 <jstoldt> but it'd be nice if you could act on core.copy.targetdoc.hint today... and there is also still XWIKI-5701 around for a while...  
11:13 <vmassol> jstoldt: done re the reword  
11:13 <jstoldt> nice! :)  
11:28 <Enygma`> has joined #xwiki  
11:43 <jvdrean> has joined #xwiki  
11:47 <sabageru> has quit  
12:08 <evalica> has joined #xwiki  
12:32 <vmassol> guys if you want to check the quality of xwiki's core module: http://nemo.sonarsource.org/components/index/207147  
12:32 <vmassol> we have a few B and some C  
12:32 <vmassol> note that integration tests are not taken into account (only unit tests)  
12:32 <vmassol> (unit tests = tests in the same module than the code it's testing)  
12:41 <@cjdelisle> hello all  
12:41 <@cjdelisle> "Hi Caleb, you certainly don't need a jira issue for this... "  
12:41 <vmassol> hi cjdelisle  
12:42 <@cjdelisle> If you don't mind, I'd much rather follow a strict rule.  
12:42 <vmassol> it's ok, my comment was just that it's not needed  
12:43 <vmassol> it's the "Rule: Don't create unnecessary issues" on http://dev.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Community/DevelopmentPractices#HJIRABestPractices  
12:43 <@cjdelisle> "All committs to the tree have a issue number, no issue is committed against after it has been closed and there has been a release"  
12:43 <vmassol> what is this?  
12:43 <@cjdelisle> The rule I have been going by thus far.  
12:44 <@cjdelisle> It's easier for me to just follow a protocol than to have to make a judgement call each time "is this big enough to warrant an issue?"  
12:45 <vmassol> it's a lot of work for not much that's all  
12:45 <vmassol> you have more bureaucracy work than real production thing in this case  
12:45 <vmassol> then the release manager also has more work  
12:45 <vmassol> since he needs to sort out important things to put in the release notes (ie he needs to exclude stuff from them)  
12:46 <vmassol> but again it's ok, just don't expect others to do it too :)  
12:46 <@cjdelisle> I can skip issues just as well, but I need to know when to skip and when to create them.  
12:47 <vmassol> well we use to skip jira at least for: javadoc improvements, internal reafctoring, checkstyle fixes  
12:47 <vmassol> I'm sure there are more  
12:47 <@cjdelisle> I can follow any rule you'd like, what I have a hard time with is guessing.  
12:47 <vmassol> again it's ok  
12:48 <vmassol> I was just commenting on jira to help you avoid unnecessary work that's all  
12:48 <vmassol> (in case you wanted to avoid it)  
12:48 <@cjdelisle> Unnecessary work > unnecessary thinking & worrying if I got it right  
12:49 <@cjdelisle> "don't expect others to do it too" A lot of things I'm rather strict about I do them so I give everyone else the benefit of assuming they are strict about how they do thngs too.  
12:50 <@cjdelisle> \*there was an "the way" which went in there somewhere.  
12:50 <vmassol> yeah we shouldn't be too strict  
12:51 <@cjdelisle> That is to say, I'm strict with myself.  
12:51 <vmassol> our rules should either be unanimous or should allow liberty if there's no way to define them strictly  
12:52 <vmassol> personally what I'm trying to do in general is balance  
12:52 <vmassol> the paperwork vs the benfits of them regarding prodcution of runtime code  
12:52 <vmassol> so minimal paperwork required to get the runtime code we need  
12:52 <@cjdelisle> Stuff like using "final", often it has no real benefit other than making the compiler enforce that the code does what I intend it to do. I'd never ask other people to do that.  
12:52 <vmassol> re final I've always been ambivalent  
12:53 <vmassol> I've read severzl things about it  
12:53 <vmassol> in places htey recommend using it  
12:53 <vmassol> in other they strictly say you shouldn't use it  
12:53 <@cjdelisle> ^never heard that one.  
12:53 <vmassol> since the compiler will do it by itself (AFAIR)  
12:53 <vmassol> they call it overoptimization  
12:54 <@cjdelisle> I do it because it declares that I don't intend to change that variable. It is self documenting.  
12:54 <@cjdelisle> Perfect exmple of the sort of thing I'd never ask someone else to do.  
12:55 <vmassol> yes that's the good point… the bad point is what happens with the String class for ex and several other from the JDK that you cannot extend  
12:56 <@cjdelisle> Oh I never ever declare a class final unless there is a compelling security reason.  
12:56 <@cjdelisle> ^that I would complain about if I saw it ;)  
12:56 <vmassol> so you're talking only about final params?  
12:57 <@cjdelisle> final parameters, local variables and fields.  
12:57 <@cjdelisle> You see one non final local variable in a mess of final ones, you ar alerted that it will be changed.  
12:58 <@cjdelisle> OTOH, final everything makes the jvm allow you to do horrible things with inner classes.  
12:58 <vmassol> well for me java should all be final  
12:58 <vmassol> btw AFAIR final doesn't prevent a param from being modified  
12:59 <vmassol> (if it's an object passed - only the ref is final)  
12:59 <@cjdelisle> Yes, that is indeed a gotcha.  
12:59 <@cjdelisle> final != const  
13:00 <vmassol> in any case findbugs reports when code modified params  
13:00 <vmassol> as a major viomation  
13:00 <@cjdelisle> Another gotcha is there's a bug in the sun jvm where final local primitives sometimes are reset to 0.  
13:01 <vmassol> http://nemo.sonarsource.org/plugins/resource/207147?page=org.sonar.plugins.core.hotspots.GwtHotspots is interesting  
13:01 <vmassol> wow we have a unit test method that takes 5mn  
13:02 <vmassol> javascript:;  
13:02 <vmassol> wow 10 minutes in security unit tests  
13:02 <@cjdelisle> xwiki-crypto?  
13:02 <vmassol> yes  
13:02 <@cjdelisle> IIRC there was a bit of key generation there. That's too long though.  
13:02 <vmassol> http://nemo.sonarsource.org/resource/index/org.xwiki.platform:xwiki-core-crypto:org.xwiki.crypto.passwd.ScryptMemoryHardKeyDerivationFunctionTest?metric=test\_execution\_time  
13:03 <@cjdelisle> ScryptMemoryHardKeyDerivationFunctionTest?metric=test\_execution\_time  
13:03 <@cjdelisle> -->MemoryHardKeyDerivationFunction<--  
13:04 <@cjdelisle> It's meant to be hard but 10 minutes is way too hard.  
13:05 <@cjdelisle> I looks like the logic for determining how much work should be required is not correct.  
13:05 <@cjdelisle> No, actually I think the machine it's running on is memory starved.  
13:06 <@cjdelisle> So it's running GC cycles to get the 1MB needed to do the function.  
13:06 <@cjdelisle> 151760 ms. scryptConformanceTest2 <-- this is a predefined function, it should not take very long.  
13:07 <SvenDowideit\_> has joined #xwiki  
13:08 <SvenDowideit> has quit  
13:08 <SvenDowideit\_> is now known as <SvenDowideit>  
13:08 <SvenDowideit> has quit  
13:08 <SvenDowideit> has joined #xwiki  
13:10 <@cjdelisle> Running org.xwiki.crypto.passwd.ScryptMemoryHardKeyDerivationFunctionTest  
13:10 <@cjdelisle> Tests run: 14, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 7.29 sec  
13:10 <@cjdelisle> My guess is it's running on a memory starved box.  
13:14 <vmassol> ok so we consider it normal?  
13:14 <vmassol> (7 sec is still a lot for unit tests)  
13:14 <vmassol> (that's the time taken to execute 1200 unit tests by the rendering engine)  
13:15 <@cjdelisle> It's meant to be hard to turn a password into a key, that's why the long time.  
13:16 <@cjdelisle> 100ms + 1MB of ram to validate a key.  
13:16 <@cjdelisle> running brute force with 1 million password guesses takes 100,000 MB/seconds of computer horsepower.  
13:18 <vmassol> ok  
13:18 <@cjdelisle> The reference implementation takes 100MB 5 seconds, but that's just plain paranoia.  
13:18 <vmassol> we'll need to decide at some point if they're executed in the default build or not  
13:19 <vmassol> 7s is not that much but it adds up  
13:19 <@cjdelisle> Yea, they really don't need to be run all of the time. Nothing really changes in the crypto module.  
13:21 <@cjdelisle> As soon as this database I'm writing is done, I can put all my effort into a macro which allows the contentAuthor to change if the content inside of it is signed.  
13:21 <jstoldt> what is that supposed to do?  
13:22 <@cjdelisle> Basically, anything which has no signature runs with almost no permissions.  
13:24 <@cjdelisle> So if I have programming permission, I can write script anywhere from a comment to a document to an object.  
13:24 <@cjdelisle> All I have to do is sign it.  
13:24 <@cjdelisle> And if I don't want to give it that power, I just don't sign.  
13:24 <florinciu> has joined #xwiki  
13:25 <jstoldt> so you mean you want to create a macro which would grant a document a certain set of rights regardless of who the last author of the page is? am i getting what you are saying?  
13:26 <@cjdelisle> Only what is inside of the macro.  
13:27 <jstoldt> ah, still sounds like a neat idea. however, what i wonder about, wouldn't that allow users to make use of other users permissions? or will it be validated upon saving for the first time?  
13:28 <@cjdelisle> So I can be like: {{signed}} {{groovy}} println('hello world'); {{/groovy}} {{signature}}WFHfahsDDhfFdktuTaEgfFasFsfh.....{{/signed}}  
13:28 <jstoldt> i imagine it this will require rather extensive changes  
13:29 <@cjdelisle> I think it can be patched in to the current system pretty easy, for best security we should make everythign ask the "notary" before doing anythign requiring permissions though.  
13:29 <jstoldt> hmmm  
13:29 <@cjdelisle> And every time that code is rendered, it will be validated. If it fails validation, it will not run.  
13:29 <jstoldt> sounds like you love thinking about millions of possibilities when coding stuff ;)  
13:30 <@cjdelisle> If anyone changes anything between {{signed}} and {{/signed}} the it won't run.  
13:30 <@cjdelisle> But! you can just splice that snippet into any page, limiting that has to be enforced by the code inside of it.  
13:31 <@cjdelisle> "millions of possibilities" :)  I like security when there is a small well reviewed well understood piece of code onwhich all security depends.  
13:31 <jstoldt> sounds all pretty nice.  
13:32 <jstoldt> yeah. i mean the idea is great but it will remain an "advanced" feature, imo  
13:32 <@cjdelisle> AKA every time you attack the system, you end up staring at that signature validating code.  
13:32 <@cjdelisle> Like a bottle neck.  
13:33 <jstoldt> mhmm  
13:33 <@cjdelisle> We can do "one click signing" easy enough.  
13:34 <jstoldt> yeah, the signing is also something to be considered in detail... i mean using private and public key won't very well work, i guess  
13:34 <@cjdelisle> the crypto module actually supports validating signatures made by firefox with a key in the ff key store.  
13:34 <jstoldt> so you're stuck with only a public key which needs to be validated upon initial save, i think  
13:34 <@cjdelisle> AKA you could root the server and you still wouldn't be able to sign stuff lol  
13:34 <jstoldt> that may be but what about people using other browsers...  
13:35 <vmassol> and it's not very wiki in the spirit  
13:35 <vmassol> you sign something and nobody else can change it  
13:35 <vmassol> (needs to be resigned)  
13:35 <@cjdelisle> True enough, but for PR code, noone should be able to change it.  
13:36 <jstoldt> well, if it's code i don't think it's very objectionable because whoever should be able to change it should also have enough rights to sign himself  
13:36 <@cjdelisle> ^that  
13:37 <@cjdelisle> What it means to the world though is I can introduce a groovy script which presents an api and anyone can paste that script into myxwiki.org and use the api which I presented.  
13:37 <vmassol> question: do we need a jira issue when we remove deprecated method? … hmmm…. I'm tempted towards no  
13:37 <@cjdelisle> hehe you're call ;)  
13:37 <@cjdelisle> \*your  
13:37 <jstoldt> i can definately think this is a nice addition for coders, like running shell commands via XWiki, but from a customer POV i only see an advantage when somebody is adding code to a page which needs to be changed by the less privelged customer...  
13:38 <vmassol> (provided it respects the rule for removing deprecated methods of course)  
13:38 <jstoldt> needs to be changed content wise, that is  
13:38 <vmassol> cjdelisle: seen my mail about it?  
13:38 <vmassol> (waiting for some replies)  
13:40 <jstoldt> also, what should be taken into consideration regarding the whole sign macro would be that there could be a need for nesting... like i want to write something dynamically and the crucial part has to be signed and if it's not we do nothing or show a warning  
13:40 <@cjdelisle> I see. We're sort of in quicksand with the public api. Nothing we can really do there.  
13:40 <@cjdelisle> hence my reservedness at adding anything new.  
13:41 <vmassol> cjdelisle: it doesn't change anything  
13:41 <@cjdelisle> jstoldt: You mean to say that you want to have something which requires an admin's privilege signed by an admin and inside of that inclide a bit which requires a programmer?  
13:42 <vmassol> having to drop 500 methods or 600 doesn't change  
13:42 <vmassol> we'll drop them all at once  
13:42 <vmassol> by offering a migration path  
13:42 <jstoldt> cjdelisle: yeah, something like that.  
13:42 <@cjdelisle> haha Interesting, I'm talking about signed macro, you're talking about old api.  
13:42 <jstoldt> i wouldn't know ;)  
13:43 <florinciu> has quit  
13:43 <@cjdelisle> Brilliant! We can make the old api into groovy and sign it then anyone can pull it in to the code which needs it.  
13:43 <jstoldt> but yeah, the basic idea is that if you want to cover everything there might be a need for some nesting for all i can see  
13:43 <vmassol> cjdelisle: 1378 deprecated calls used in xwiki: http://nemo.sonarsource.org/drilldown/violations/207147?rids%5B%5D=215556&rule=squid%3ACallToDeprecatedMethod#  
13:43 <florinciu> has joined #xwiki  
13:44 <sburjan> has quit  
13:44 <polx> has quit  
13:44 <@cjdelisle> Yup, nesting dignatures will be supported although nesting script macros is not and should not be.  
13:44 <@cjdelisle> \*signatures  
13:45 <jstoldt> by old api you mean some old, deprecated api and you suggest a way to be able to remove it while still being able to use it if needed, right?  
13:45 <sburjan> has joined #xwiki  
13:46 <@cjdelisle> Yes! :D  
13:47 <jstoldt> hmmm okay, i feel dumber by the second but apparently i help you finding ideas! yay! ;)  
13:47 <@cjdelisle> I have thought it would be cool to have a web server which would execute \_anything\_ you posted to it.  
13:47 <@cjdelisle> As long as it had a valid signature.  
13:48 <@cjdelisle> ~1000 lines of code for the server. Everything else is sent from the client side.  
13:49 <jstoldt> well, that would be nice but, again, the common user will not benefit an awful lot for all he can see  
13:49 <jstoldt> you'll be stuck with enthusiasts and probably one company building solutions ontop of that  
13:50 <@cjdelisle> ^yea, that's more the way I'd run a website for myself.  
14:06 <@cjdelisle> vmassol: when do you expect to have time to look at [proposal] Introduce a new persistence engine.?  
14:08 <vmassol> cjdelisle: before end of the week  
14:08 <@cjdelisle> Thanks  
14:11 <vmassol> ping me again tomorrow please  
14:11 <vmassol> (in case I forget)  
14:11 <@cjdelisle> No pb, that I can do :)  
14:11 <lucaa> has quit  
14:15 <florinciu> has quit  
14:24 <lucaa> has joined #xwiki  
14:34 <lucaa> has quit  
14:37 <lucaa> has joined #xwiki  
15:20 <vmassol> has quit  
15:26 <+sburjan> bug. it was me :))  
15:36 <mflorea> has quit  
15:41 <jstoldt> i'm out. bye  
15:41 <jstoldt> has quit  
16:07 <+sburjan> do we have in UI a page to trigger the Watchlist Scheduler ?  
16:08 <+sburjan> I know we had this, but we removed .. so it's not in the UI anymore  
16:09 <+sburjan> found, thanks  
16:24 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki  
16:42 <vmassol1> has joined #xwiki  
16:43 <vmassol> has quit  
16:59 <sburjan> has quit  
17:30 <evalica> has quit  
17:57 <npm> has joined #xwiki  
18:01 <npm\_\_> has quit  
18:21 <vmassol1> lucaa: question for you. Why do we have  {{tagcloud  space="" /}} rather than  {{tagcloud/}} for the main dashboard?  
18:21 <vmassol1> (I'd also like to get rid of $util since it's not recommended to use it and supposed to be deprecated)  
18:36 <+lucaa> vmassol1: lemme check, maybe by mistake?  
18:37 <vmassol1> lucaa: no it's not a mistake you wanted to reuse a few chars I think  
18:38 <@cjdelisle> Maybe we could use velocity initializers to move things like $util out of the default .war into a compatbility .jar.  
18:42 <vmassol1> lucaa: what about this instead: http://pastebin.com/kgvHqhCJ  
18:42 <vmassol1> ?  
18:42 <+lucaa> sure  
18:42 <vmassol1> I've removed unnecessary comments and #set  
18:42 <vmassol1> do you like it better?  
18:43 <+lucaa> I think I know why that, it was a leftover from the time when the dahsboard had titles in there  
18:43 <+lucaa> or something...  
18:43 <+lucaa> now the titles are generated by the dashboard  
18:43 <+lucaa> I agree  
18:44 <vmassol1> titles are of the wrong size btw  
18:44 <vmassol1> how are titles generated?  
18:46 <+lucaa> they are h2s  
18:46 <+lucaa> we discussed about this
